text:
Fifth Ave., east side, south from East 42nd to 41st Streets. Building shown, is Rutgers Female College (founded 1838 by Chancellor Ferris). This photograph was presented to the graduating class of 1875. This institution lost this property, at a later date, and moved to 56 West 55th Street.

1875.

Gift of Mrs. C.M. Benson.

Fifth Avenue, east side, from East 41st (right) to 44th (extreme left)Streets as viewed from the Reservoir. At the right is Rutgers Female College founded in 1838 by Chancellor Ferris occupying the 41st-42nd Street frontage. Later they will move to 56 West 55th Street. Temple Emanu-El is at the N.E. corner of 43rd Street. Erected in 1868, it will be removed in 1927 for the Lafcourt-National Bldg.
About 1875
H.N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events: The General U. S. Grant funeral procession moving northward on Fifth Avenue as photographed from 41st Street atop the old reservoir. The dominant structure with flag atop is the Union League Club at the N. E. corner of 39th Street.

August 8, 1885

H. N. Tiemann, Photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - U. S. Grant's Funeral.

text: Fifth Avenue north from 41st Street, showing pupils of the Spence School for Girls out for their daily walk. At the extreme left is the reservoir which for many years covered the site now occupied by the New York Public Library. In the left background is the Bristol office building, formerly the Hotel Bristol. This was demolished in 1929 to make way for the Salmon Tower. The spires of St. Patrick's Cathedral may be dimly seen in the right background. Temple Emanu-El, demolished in 1927 is the spired building in the centre. 1900. Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

Celebrations and Municipal Events:
Suffragette Parade on Fifth Avenue, passing reviewing stand in front of the Public Library at 41st Street,
Ewing Galloway, Photographer
1913
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Suffragette Parade.

text: 6, 4 East 41st Street, adjoining the S.E. corner of Fifth Avenue. These buildings will be demolished in 1925. About 1915.

North on Fifth Avenue from 41st Street, showing Bristol Hotel, converted into office building, at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and 42nd Street. Temple Emanu-El is right center.

Irving Underhill, Photographer
1919

Fifth Ave., east side, south from East 41st Street. Prominent building shown, is No. 10 East 40th Street.

June 24, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Fifth Avenue, east side, from 41st to 42nd Streets, from steps of the New York Public Library. In the foreground may be seen part of a picket line which was conducted for some weeks against the Fifth Avenue Omnibus Company in connection with the discharge of twenty-seven employees. The outcome of the dispute is unknown.
July 6, 1935.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(2)
A view at 42nd Street.

July 2, 1936.

P. L. Sperr.

1936.

Fifth Ave., west side, at 41st Street (main entrance to the N. Y. P. L.).
A photo showing "Beauty" seated on "Pegasus" and mounted in the south niche. This is by Frederick Macmonnies. For further data, see The History of the New York Public Library by H.M. Lydenberg (page 509).

July 14, 1936.

Gift of G.D. Chinn.

Celebrations, Parades, and Municipal Events: The American Legion parade. A set of three views photographed from atop the south wing of the New York Public Library and showing units marching northward on Fifth Ave. at 41st Street. Note the stands in the foreground.

September 21, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal Events - American Legion Parade.

text:
Fifth Ave., west side, north from 41st to 42nd (right) Streets, showing the north wing of the Central Building of the New York Public Library as photographed at dusk (6:30 P.M.). Skyscrapers on the north side of West 42nd Street are in their order, the No. 500 Fifth Ave. Building; the Salmon Towers and the Aeolian Building.

March 17, 1938.

Mr. Nathan Schwartz.
New York Public Library.

Fifth Avenue, west side, at 41st Street, showing the main entrance to the New York Public Library as photographed at night.

February 1939

Mr. Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library

Fifth Avenue,west side, at 41st Street, showing the New York
Public Library and one of its watchful lions.

Winter 1939

Alexander Alland

This photo is one of a series that appeared in the published volume "Portraits of N. Y." by Felix Reisenberg and Alex. Alland, IROV.

Fifth Avenue, west side, at 41st Street, showing the north unit of the pair, "Leo dormant," that guard the New York Public Library esplanade entrance. This photo taken the morning after a snowstorm.

February 16, 1940,

Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library
Photostat Division

Fifth Avenue, west side, at 41st Street. The sign board on the esplanade announcing the Gutenberg Exhibition. This photo taken the morning after a snowstorm.

February 16, 1940

Nathan Schwartz
New York Public Library
Photostat Division

Street Scenes: Political harangue on the New York Public Library steps in the Roosevelt-Wilkie presidential contest. This speaker is pro-Roosevelt; the Wilkie orator is to the left and not shown. In the right background is the base of the office structure, No. 500 Fifth Avenue.

Fall 1940

Nathan Schwartz, photo
N.Y.P.L. Photostat div.

Street Scenes: Political harangue on the New York Public Library Steps in the Roosevelt-Wilkie presidential contest. This speaker is pro-Roosevelt; the Wilkie orator is to the left and not shown. Incidentally, the latter making use of a microphone drew larger crowds. Credit for the adaptation of this technic should be given to the U. S. Senatorial candidate, Bruce Barton, an advertising executive.

Fall 1940

Nathan Schwartz, photo
N.Y.P.L. Photostat div.

Female College.
